text: * i-nodes * A Unix file is described by an information block called an i-node. There is an i-node on disc for every file on the disc and there is also a copy in kernel memory for every open file. All the information about a file, other than it's name, is stored in the i-node. This information includes * File access and type information, collectively known as the mode. * File ownership information. * Time stamps for last modification, last access and last mode modification. * Link count. * File size in bytes. * Addresses of physical blocks.
